items.title: CA1062 null check validation methods (for guard clauses) with nullable reference types
items.body:
I have created a small `dotnetstandard 2.1` library project in a solution.  I want to test out using [Nullable Reference Types](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/nullable-references).  As part of this, I want to have appropriate compilation errors and warnings.

TLDR;
I want to know how to setup the CA1062 code quality settings in `.editorconfig` correctly.

## Library Project

I have added the following `nuget` packages to the project:
```
<ItemGroup>
	  <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Analyzers" Version="2.9.8">
		  <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
		  <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
	  </PackageReference>
	  <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.FxCopAnalyzers" Version="2.9.8">
		  <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
		  <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
	  </PackageReference>
	  <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.CSharp" Version="4.7.0" />
		<PackageReference Include="Ardalis.GuardClauses" Version="1.4.2" />
  </ItemGroup>
```

This includes the various code analysis packages and also Steve Smith's nice [Guard Clauses](https://github.com/ardalis/GuardClauses) library.

Nullable Reference Types has been enabled using `<Nullable>enable</Nullable>` in the project.  

And I have a class which in the real world would be a nice implementation that actually did something:
```
using System;
using MyGuards;

namespace EditorConfigIssues
{
    public static class TestEditorConfig
	{
		public static void TestMethod(MyParam input)
		{
			string x = input.Check;
			Console.WriteLine(x);
		}
	}

	public class MyParam
	{
		public MyParam(string check) => Check = check;

		public string Check { get; }
	}
}
```

## Guard Library Project

In the solution I have added a simple Guard library which is another `dotnetstandard 2.1` project.

```
using System;

namespace MyGuards
{
	public static class FakeGuard
	{
		public static void Validate(object obj)
		{
			if (obj == null)
				throw new ArgumentNullException();
		}
	}
}
```

NOTE: This is not in competition of the GuardClauses library - just using to contrast editorconfig with!

## .editorconfig

I have added an `.editorconfig` to the root of solution with the following diagnostic checks:

```
dotnet_diagnostic.CA1062.severity = error
dotnet_code_quality.CA1062.exclude_extension_method_this_parameter = true
```

So with this in place, when I compile I get the following:
[![Errors][1]][1]

So everything is as I expect so far.  I am not using any guards yet.

## Fixing it up - Steve Smith's Guard Library

So lets try and implement the guard clauses from Steve Smiths Guard Library to get rid of the error.

So we add the following to `TestEditorConfig.TestMethod`:

```
Guard.Against.Null(input, nameof(input));
```

and tweak the `.editorconfig` with:

```
dotnet_code_quality.CA1062.null_check_validation_methods = Ardalis.GuardClauses.Guard.Against.Null
```

Excellent, all is good.  The error has disappeared.
[![Initial error gone][2]][2]

## Fixing it up - my own guard library

But now I want to use my own guard.  So we replace the initial guard check in `TestEditorConfig.TestMethod` with:

```
FakeGuard.Validate(input);
```

and replace the null_check_validation_methods in `.editorconfig` with:

```
dotnet_code_quality.CA1062.null_check_validation_methods = FakeGuard.Validate
```

The error is now back.  
[![enter image description here][3]][3]


## Question(s)

1. The question is, what do I need in order to use a project with guards from the same solution?
2. Why am I getting warnings for the other CA1062 in the Error Window?
```
The keyword "dotnet_code_quality.CA1062.exclude_extension_method_this_parameter" is unknown
The keyword "dotnet_code_quality.CA1062.null_check_validation_methods" is unknown
```

I have been checking out this link [MS Docs Code Quality](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/code-quality/ca1062?view=vs-2019) and tried various combinations for the FakeGuard, including: 

* MyGuards
* MyGuards.FakeGuard
* FakeGuard
* MyGuards.FakeGuard.Validate
* FakeGuard.Validate
* Validate

Curiously, in a different solution, then I don't get any complaints about the CA1062 editorconfig settings in the Error Window.  And in there I have been unable to get the `null_check_validation_methods` working - hence putting together this solution.  This has been bugging me for a month or two, but finally getting the energy to put things together at the moment.

## EditorConfig Bug?

If I copy the FakeGuard file to the Library project, then the error message disappears.  But why does this not work in a different project in the solution.

  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/kgXSC.png
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/LPUHB.png

items.title: insert_final_newline = true and empty files
items.body:
I wonder how an editorconfig processor should behave with `insert_final_newline = true` for an empty file? Should it (a) leave it as is or (b) should it add a line separator?

### Background

My [editorconfig-maven-plugin](https://github.com/ec4j/editorconfig-maven-plugin) currently requires the line delimiter even in empty files and I got a [user report](https://github.com/ec4j/editorconfig-maven-plugin/issues/43) claiming that the behavior is not compatible with some python tooling.

When searching for some editorconfig recommendations in this area, I just found a similar unresolved eclint issue https://github.com/jedmao/eclint/issues/156
So I guess there is no editorconfig-wide consensus about the matter.

### Solution proposal

I understand the `insert_final_newline` as a means for enforcing files to comply with the [POSIX definition of text file](https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/xrat/V4_xbd_chap03.html#tag_21_03_00_83) That definition explicitly says that it

> allows a file with a single <newline>, or a totally empty file, to be called a text file.

So I think it should be OK to let an editorconfig processor to leave an empty file as is even with `insert_final_newline = true`

WDYT?

items.title: CI Tests: check all files for compliance with .editorconfig rules
items.body:
Picture the following scenario:

- I run an open source project
- My project has a `.editorconfig` file
- My project has continuous integration tests on [Travis CI](https://travis-ci.org/) (or similar)
- The tests are run every time somebody submits a pull request to my project (and on every commit)

When contributors submit pull requests to my project, I'd like to check all changed files against the rules defined in `.editorconfig`. (This would be a kind of "sanity check" before the main tests are run.)

- I want the CI test to fail if somebody submits code that violates the rules in `.editorconfig`.
- The test will print a list of files that failed, and why each file failed.
- The test would inform contributors that they can visit https://editorconfig.org/ for instructions on how to setup their preferred editor/IDE so that their code will pass the test automatically.

Example output of test program:

```
./editorconfig-sanity-check: checking code files against rules in .editorconfig

README.md - Line 17 - trailing whitespace detected (trim_trailing_whitespace = TRUE)
docs/index.html - Line 4 - character 33 is invalid (charset = UTF-8)
src/module.py - Line 62 - indentation TAB detected (indent_style = SPACE)

items.title: Define which EOL should insert_final_newline use if end_of_line is not defined
items.body:
Given that `file.txt` does not end with a newline and given that `insert_final_newline = true` is the only property applicable to `file.txt`, which end of line string should the processor take to insert at the end of `file.txt`?

Clearly, if the `end_of_line` property is defined for `file.txt`, the processor can take its value. But what should the processor do if `end_of_line` is undefined?

I can think of the following options:

(1) If `file.txt` contains any EOL, use the last one, otherwise do nothing (or at least warn that `end_of_line` should be defined)

(2) Do nothing (or at least warn that `end_of_line` should be defined)

(3) Use `\n` as a hard coded default.

I think (1) is the proper solution for most cases.

I think (3) is generally wrong, because there probably exist languages where `\n` is not allowed.

Any other ideas?

items.title: Add Plugin Guidelines for Each Property
items.body:
I propose adding a section to the [Plugin-How-To section of the wiki](https://github.com/editorconfig/editorconfig/wiki/Plugin-How-To) that offers guidelines about how to implement each EditorConfig property.

Some rules are best implemented the moment you open a file, but others may only apply on each file save. We probably need some clarity there.

To kick-off the discussion, let me make a list and we can modify it as the discussion evolves.

## `indent_style`

1. When opening/switching to a file, apply built-in editor setting.
1. If no built-in editor setting, do nothing. Do not attempt to fix indent style with manual operations.

## `indent_size`

1. When opening/switching to a file, apply built-in editor setting.
1. If no built-in editor setting, do nothing. Do not attempt to fix indent size with manual operations.

## `tab_width`

1. When opening/switching to a file, apply built-in editor setting.
1. If no built-in editor setting, do nothing. Manual operations do not apply to this property.

## `end_of_line`

1. When opening/switching to a file, apply built-in editor setting. In some editors, this will mark the file as dirty.
1. If no built-in editor setting, apply built-in editor operation on file save.
1. If no built-in editor operation, apply manual operation on file save or do nothing.

## `charset`
1. When opening/switching to a file, apply built-in editor setting.
1. If no built-in editor setting, apply manual operation on file save or do nothing.

## `trim_trailing_whitespace`
1. Do not attempt to fix trailing whitespace when opening/switching to a file.
1. Apply built-in editor setting on file save.
1. If no built-in editor setting, apply manual operation on file save or do nothing.

## `insert_final_newline`

1. Do not attempt to insert a final new line when opening/switching to a file.
1. On file save, apply built-in editor setting.
1. If no built-in editor setting, apply manual operation on file save or do nothing.

items.title: Feature request: start_block_style and end_block_style
items.body:
Some of the suggested properties e.g. curly_bracket_next_line and indent_brace_style and spaces_around_brackets seem to be a little too language-specific and worse, indent_brace_style would require me to not only know the style, but who invented it! Granted, Wikipedia will tell me but who wants to memorize K&$ vs Allman? Not me.
How about a more general property such as begin_block_style? This would allow the inclusion of folks that use languages like Delphi (which uses a "Begin"/"End" pair to delineate code blocks?
The complete set of properties might include the following:

`start_block_style="<some delimiter>":<code location>:<style>:<allow inline comment>:<pad left>:<pad right>:<vertical tab before>:<vertical tab after>`

`"<some delimiter>"` - Many languages allow more than one code block start delimiter e.g. in Delphi code blocks start with the word "begin", in C# array declarations start with a left bracket ( [ ) and property initializers use a left brace ( { ), most languages use a left parentheses ( ( ) to start parameter declarations. The delimiter is enclosed in double quotes.

`<code location>` - this entry can take on one of the following values:
 - declaration - when the delimiter is found in the declaration portion of a code statement.
 - body - when the delimiter is found in the body of a code statement.

`<allow inline comment>` - this entry can take on one of the following values:
 - true - allow an inline comment on the same line as the delimiter
 - false - do not allow an inline comment on the same line as the delimiter

`<style>` - this entry can take on one of the following values:
 - isolated - the delimiter is on its own line allowing no other code save inline comments.
 - inline - the delimiter is just part of the code declaration.
 - same_line - the delimiter is the first non white-space item on the line but allows other code to follow on the same line.
 - break_to_new_line_before - at the point in the code where the delimiter is found, insert a newline before the delimiter and place the delimiter and all following code on the next line, indented as specified.
 - break_to_new_line_after - at the point in the code where the delimiter is found, insert a newline after the delimiter and place the code that follows on the next line, indented as specified.
 - as_is - don't mess with the current formatting, pad and vertical tab values will be ignored.

`<pad left>` - after the style has been applied to the location of the delimiter, insert the specified number of indent_size indents relative to the beginning of the declaration or the previous line of code in the body BEFORE the delimiter is rendered. If an "s" modifier is used e.g. 3s, instead of using indent_size indents, the value is converted to spaces and the appropriate number of spaces will be inserted or that number of spaces will be converted to the appropriate number of tab_size + left over spaces and inserted as appropriate. If a combination of indent_size indents and spaces is desired, use the "i" modifier to identify indents e.g. 3 indents and 1 space would be set as 3i1s.

`<pad right>` - after the style has been applied, the pad_left value applied, the delimiter itself rendered, add the specified right padding to the delimiter AFTER the delimiter has been rendered. If an "s" modifier is used e.g. 3s, instead of using indent_size indents, the value is converted to spaces and the appropriate number of spaces will be inserted or that number of spaces will be converted to the appropriate number of tab_size + left over spaces and inserted as appropriate.  If a combination of indent_size indents and spaces is desired, use the "i" modifier to identify indents e.g. 3 indents and 1 space would be set as 3i1s.

`<vertical tab before>` - after the style has been applied but BEFORE any padding is applied, insert the specified number of newlines, then render the padding, then the delimiter, then the vertical_tab_after.

`<vertical tab after>` - number of newlines to be added after the delimiter has been rendered.

And, of course, the corersponding end_block_style property:

` end_block_style="<some delimiter>":<code location>:<style>:<allow inline comment>:<pad left>:<pad right>:<vertical tab before>:<vertical tab after>`

`"<some delimiter>"` - Many languages allow more than one code block end delimiter e.g. in Delphi code a program declaration ends with "end.", a method declaration ends with "end;" and a code block ends with "end" (the difference being that a program "end" ends with a period, a declaration "end" ends with a semi-colon and a code block "end" is just "end"). In C#, a declaration ends with just a right brace ( "}" ) but a statement block ends with a right brace and semi-colon ( "};} ). The delimiter is enclosed in double quotes.

`<code location>` - this entry can take on one of the following values:
 - declaration - when the delimiter is found in the declaration portion of a code statement.
 - body - when the delimiter is found in the body of a code statement.

`<allow inline comment>` - this entry can take on one of the following values:
 - true - allow an inline comment on the same line as the delimiter
 - false - do not allow an inline comment on the same line as the delimiter

`<style>` - this entry can take on one of the following values:
 - isolated - the delimiter is on its own line allowing no other code save inline comments.
 - inline - the delimiter is just part of the code declaration.
 - same_line - the delimiter is the first non white-space item on the line but allows other code to follow on the same line.
 - break_to_new_line_before - at the point in the code where the delimiter is found, insert a crlf before the delimiter and place the delimiter and all following code on the next line, indented as specified.
 - break_to_new_line_after - at the point in the code where the delimiter is found, insert a crlf after the delimiter and place the code that follows on the next line, indented as specified.
 - line_up - line up with the corresponding start delimiter. <pad left> values will be ignored.
 - as_is - don't mess with the current formatting, pad and vertical tab values will be ignored.

`<pad left>` - after the style has been applied to the location of the delimiter, insert the specified number of indent_size indents relative to the beginning of the declaration or the previous line of code in the body BEFORE the delimiter is rendered. If an "s" modifier is used e.g. 3s, instead of using indent_size indents, the value is converted to spaces and the appropriate number of spaces will be inserted or that number of spaces will be converted to the appropriate number of tab_size + left over spaces and inserted as appropriate. If a combination of indent_size indents and spaces is desired, use the "i" modifier to identify indents e.g. 3 indents and 1 space would be set as 3i1s.

`<pad right>` - after the style has been applied, the pad_left value applied, the delimiter itself rendered, add the specified right padding to the delimiter AFTER the delimiter has been rendered. If an "s" modifier is used e.g. 3s, instead of using indent_size indents, the value is converted to spaces and the appropriate number of spaces will be inserted or that number of spaces will be converted to the appropriate number of tab_size + left over spaces and inserted as appropriate. If a combination of indent_size indents and spaces is desired, use the "i" modifier to identify indents e.g. 3 indents and 1 space would be set as 3i1s.

`<vertical tab before>` - after the style has been applied but BEFORE any padding is applied, insert the specified number of newlines, then render the padding, then the delimiter, then the vertical_tab_after.

`<vertical tab after>` - number of newlines to be added after the delimiter has been rendered.

Code samples:

Delphi:
start_block_style="(" : declaration : break_to_new_line_before : false: 1 : 1s : 0 : 0
start_block_style="begin" : declaration : isolated : false : 1 : 0 : 2 : 1
end_block_style="end;" : declaration : line_up : true : -1 : 0 : 1 : 0
```
Function SomeFunction
  ( aParam: string): string


  begin

    (* some useable code goes here *)

end; // SomeFunction
```
What you see: the declaration was broken at the first encountered left paren in the declaration. Said left paren was indented 1 indent_size indent, the left paren rendered, a single space inserted and the rest of the code rendered on the same line. The "begin" has two newlines inserted and is indented one indent_size indent before rendering and a single newline after.
The "end" has been offset from the "begin" by -1 indents and is allowing inline comments.

C#:
start_block_style="(" : declaration : break_to_new_line_before : true : 0 : 0 : 0 : 1
end_block_style=")" : declaration : break_to_new_line_after : false : 0 : 0 : 1 : 1
start_block_style="{" : declaration : isolated : true : 0 : 0 : 1 : 1
end_block_style="}" : declaration : isolated : true : 0 : 0 : 1 : 0
start_block_style="{" : body : break_to_new_line_after : false : 0 : 0 : 0 : 0
end_block_style="}" : body : line_up : false : 0 : 0 : 0 : 0

```
public void someFunction
( // start param list here
  int someIntParam
  , string someStringParam

)

{

  List<string> someStrings =
    new List<string> {
                        "first value"
                        , "second value"
                     }

}
```
What you see: The start of the parameter declaration has been moved to the next line, the left paren isolated but allows inline comments. The right paren is isolated and has included a preceding newline. The starting brace is isolated and includes a preceding and following newline. The body of the code includes a left brace that is allowed to be part of the declaration and the closing brace is to line up with the opening brace.
The closing method brace is isolated and includes a preceding newline.

Javascript:
start_block_style="{" : declaration : break_to_new_line_after : false : 0 : 0 : 0 : 0
end_block_style="}" : declaration : isolated : false : 0 : 0 : 0 : 0
```
function myFunction(p1, p2) {
    return p1 * p2;              // The function returns the product of p1 and p2
}
```
What you see: The opening left paren is left on the same line as the rest of the declaration, the right paren is isolated.

items.title: Use `unset` as the standard value to turn off any option if applicable.
items.body:
This is a voting only thread.

Discussion should be at #285 .

Let's decide it before Dec 29 GMT -12 23:59

## Reserved Values
### `unset` - disables treatment of Property by editorconfig

The `unset`-keyword can be used to explicitly disable editorconfig's treatment for the given property. It is reserved so that there is confidence it shall not be used in the future for something else.

```ini
root = true;

[*]
indent_style = space
indent_size = 4
end_of_line = lf
insert_final_newline = true

[*.md]
indent_style = unset
indent_size = unset
```

In this case, for files matching `*.md`, editorconfig does not set `indent_size` and `indent_style`, while for the other files it does.

items.title: Do more specific rules override more general ones?
items.body:
The [file format details page](http://editorconfig.org/#file-format-details) describes in detail how multiple `.editorconfig` files are merged. But it doesn't specify how multiple _rules_ within a file are handled.

In our project, we have
```ini
[*]
insert_final_newline = true

[*.hbs]
insert_final_newline = false
```

In [editorconfig-sublime](https://github.com/sindresorhus/editorconfig-sublime), this does what I would expect: all files except `*.hbs` files have a final newline. In [atom-editorconfig](https://github.com/sindresorhus/atom-editorconfig), all files have a final newline.
